reference: Volume One, Issue Four, Phile #10 of 11
title: Phrack World News Issue 3 Part 2
historical_context: This article discusses the transition of the TAP magazine and the phreaking community during the mid-1980s, a time when phreaking was becoming more mainstream and facing legal scrutiny.
target_audience: Hackers, phreakers, security professionals, and those interested in hacker culture history.
short_summary: The article covers the revival of the TAP magazine by TWCB Inc., detailing the changes in editorial staff, subscription rates, and the uncertain future of the phreaking community. It also highlights the legal troubles faced by prominent figures in the hacking scene.
summary:
In this issue of Phrack World News, Knight Lightning reports on the revival of the TAP magazine, which has seen a decline in attendance at its meetings. The new editorial team, known as The W(hack)o Cracko Brothers, plans to rebrand TAP and has taken over its operations. The article outlines the subscription rates and the anticipated content for the first issue, including interviews with notable phreakers and articles from various hacking publications. The transition is marked by uncertainty, as TWCB Inc. expresses concerns about increased scrutiny from law enforcement once the magazine is published.

Furthermore, the article provides insights into the legal challenges faced by members of the phreaking community, including the case of Michael P. Wilkerson, known as The Sprinter, who was charged with hacking into multiple companies' systems. The narrative captures the tension within the community as competition arises from other publications and the looming threat of legal repercussions. Overall, this piece serves as a snapshot of the evolving landscape of hacking and phreaking during the 1980s, highlighting both the camaraderie and the challenges faced by its members.
